repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: # Problem: The swapfile "E325: ATTENTION" dialog is displayed when editing a file already open in another (running) Nvim. Usually this behavior is annoying and irrelevant: - "Recover" and the other options ("Open readonly", "Quit", "Abort") are almost never wanted. - swapfiles are less relevant for "multi-Nvim" since 'autoread' is enabled by default. - Even less relevant if user enables 'autowrite'. # Solution: Define a default SwapExists handler which does the following: 1. If the swapfile is owned by a running Nvim process (matching the current user), automatically chooses "(E)dit anyway" (caveat: this creates a new, extra swapfile, which is mostly harmless and ignored except by `:recover` or `nvim -r`. 2. Shows a 1-line "ignoring swapfile..." message. 3. Users can disable the default SwapExists handler via `autocmd! nvim.swapfile`.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
			the file can be written to.
```
English isn't my first language but "can be written" sounds kind of odd to me.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -169,33 +169,30 @@ If you want to keep the changed buffer without saving it, switch on the
 2. Editing a file					*edit-a-file*
 
 							*:e* *:edit* *reload*
-:e[dit] [++opt] [+cmd]	Edit the current file.  This is useful to re-edit the
+:e[dit][!] [++opt] [+cmd]
+			Edit the current file.  This is useful to re-edit the
 			current file, when it has been changed outside of Vim.
-			This fails when changes have been made to the current
-			buffer and 'autowriteall' isn't set or the file can't
-			be written.
-			Also see |++opt| and |+cmd|.
-
 							*:edit!* *discard*
-:e[dit]! [++opt] [+cmd]
-			Edit the current file always.  Discard any changes to
-			the current buffer.  This is useful if you want to
-			start all over again.
+			If [!] is given, unsaved changes in the current buffer
+			are discarded. Without [!] the command fails if there
+			are unsaved changes, unless 'autowriteall' is set and
+			the file can be written.

"write the file" or "write a file" appears everywhere in docs.

comment_data.body:
:) not really, but trying to be consistent at least internally. Single-word nonces work better as keywords. Also "swap file name" reads awkwardly. 

I could be persuaded to revert this though.
I don't have strong feelings about it, but I agree that "swapfile" reads better.

```suggestion
    command = [[if v:swappid > 0 | let v:swapchoice='e' | echo 'E325: Ignoring swapfile from Nvim process '..v:swappid | endif]],
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1152,6 +1152,11 @@ function vim._init_default_autocmds()
     group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim_cmdwin', {}),
     command = 'syntax sync minlines=1 maxlines=1',
   })
+  vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd({ 'SwapExists' }, {
+    pattern = '*',
+    group = vim.api.nvim_create_augroup('nvim_swapfile', {}),
+    command = [[if v:swappid > 0 | let v:swapchoice='e' | echo 'E325: ignoring swapfile from Nvim process '..v:swappid | endif]],

comment_data.body: Is this comment still relevant? I don't see any callers checking the size.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -475,7 +475,14 @@ void trunc_string(const char *s, char *buf, int room_in, int buflen)
   }
 }
 
-// Note: Caller of smsg() must check the resulting string is shorter than IOSIZE!!!
+/// Shows a printf-style message with attributes.
+///
+/// Note: Caller must check the resulting string is shorter than IOSIZE!!!

comment_regular_data.body:
With this PR the user is no longer be able to use `SwapExists` to automatically select a different option in this case.

I usually select "Abort" or "Quit" (especially on startup) as I don't want to have two Nvim instances editing the same file.

I think it's better to expose this information (whether there is a running process editing the file) to `SwapExists` autocommand, and then implement this as a default autocommand.

Changed approach, updated description.

> I think it's better to expose this information (whether there is a running process editing the file) to `SwapExists` autocommand, and then implement this as a default autocommand.

Done. 

~~Currently the pid is exposed via `v:swappid` , should it be `v:event.pid` ? Perhaps it's more consistent / less surprising to continue the `v:swap...` pattern.~~ `swapinfo()` already exposes everything that's needed.
Removing `v:swappid`, changed `swapinfo().pid` to be zero if the process is not running or was from before a reboot.

labels.description: Nvim defaults for options, colorscheme/theme, autocmds/events, etc.
labels.name: defaults

title: feat: ignore swapfile for running Nvim processes
